The MAN spits and brandishes the knife desperately, he's scrawny, sullen, bearded and filthy.If you don't put down the carving knife and get away from the godamn cart I'm going to blow your brains out.Be quiet. The MAN cocks the pistol and there's two loud CLICKS.God damn you.How long have you been following us?Take your clothes off. Take them off, every godamn stitch.I'll kill you where you stand.I won't tell you again.The shoes.The shoes. He sits naked in the road and unlaces the rotting shoes.Put them in the cart. The THIEF stands and drops the shoes in the trolley.Put the clothes in. The MAN drops the clothes in and stands there covering himself, shivering.You didn't mind doing it to us.You tried to kill us.You took everything.I'm going to leave you the way you left us.Let's go. The BOY doesn't take his hand but they set off along the blacktop, the BOY snivelling and crying, leaving the THIEF shivering and whimpering.Stop it.What do you think would have happened to him if we hadn't caught him? You've got to learn.I won't be here forever. Sooner or later you'll have to look after yourself. The BOY just looks at him - and keeps crying.You have to stop crying.He's gone. Come on.What do you want to do?He's going to die anyway.I'm scared. Do you understand? I'm scared. The MAN tries to look the BOY in the eye but he keeps his head bowed, sobbing.You're not the one who has to worry about everything. The BOY mumbles, tearful and snotty.What? What did you say?All right. Help me.Is this where we stopped?Come on. We have to go. The BOY eyes the clothes sadly, silent now.I have to get your temperature down. The BOY swallows the pills and the water, shivering.Of course you can.If you died I'd want to die too.So I could be with you, yes. But that's not going to happen. They look at each other a moment, unsure, the BOY shivering and sick-looking. The BOY lies down and shuts his eyes. The MAN puts a blanket over him. The MAN walks away a few paces and coughs endlessly, a nagging cough that won't go.How are you feeling?Are you hungry?Yes.What of it?It's a Beetle. Suddenly the beetle twitches, then activates its wings and flies out of the box with a BUZZ and upwards into the sky... The BOY and the MAN stare up at the flying creature, amazedOh you bastard! You bastard!Stay just like you are. He gets up and runs limping across the street, the arrow still embedded in his leg.Who else is up here?Where's the bow?Why are you following us?See if you can find the medical kit from the boat. Quickly. The BOY rummages in the trolley, finds the kit and hands it over. He stares as the MAN slowly extracts the spoon, wincing in agony. The MAN dowses the wound in antiseptic from the kit and searches through the kit for a needle. He finds a suture needle in a sterile envelope, rips it open with his teeth and, using the light coming in through the parlour windows he threads some silk thread into the needle. He starts to suture up the wound, grimacing in pain as the BOY watches in silence, until eventually offering:Yes! It hurts!At least you're talking to me now.Do you want me to tell you a story?Why not?They don't have to be true. They're stories.We're still here aren't we? Doesn't that mean anything?We have to leave the cart. I can't push it anymore.Don't get comfortable. You need to keep going. You don't know what might be down the road.We were always lucky. You'll be lucky again. You'll see. Just go.It's all right. This has been a long time coming. Just keep going south. Do everything the way we did it.Keep the gun with you at all times. Don't let anyone take it from you. You need to find the good guys but you can't take any chances. Do you hear me?I want to be with you too but I can't.You have to go off on your own now. You have to carry the fire.Yes you do. You know everything about it.Yes it is.Yes you do.It's inside you. It was always there. I can see it. The BOY stares at him, not sure what to believe.You have to let me go.Just hold my hand. The BOY grips the MAN's hand, bouncing up and down, agitated.I know. I'm sorry. The BOY falls on the MAN, hugging him tight, face pressed to his chest, sobbing.My boy. You have my whole heart. You always did. You're the best guy. You can talk to me and I'll talk to you. You'll see.You just will.If I were God I would have made the world just so and no different... And so I have you. .I have you.Show me. The BOY doesn't move. The MAN holds out his hand for the BOY to take, the BOY sees he has a THUMB MISSING and hesitates, wary. The MAN squats, leaning on his shotgun.

The BOY is now clinging to the MAN and crying, his head buried against his chest in fear.What was it, Papa?Now you can read me a story. He gets out a BOOK and looks at the pictures in the lamplight. The MAN reads him a story...It's snowing!Who is it?What should we do Papa?Take a look.Papa, what's wrong with that man?Can't we help him? Papa?Papa?Can't we help him, Papa?I know.I'm talking now.Yes.There could be something here. There could be corn or something.Maybe we could find some hayseeds in the hayloft? Now the BOY goes over to the swinging CORPSES, oddly curious.What does that mean?I think.Okay. The MAN puts the gun away and cuddles the BOY close. They set off again.You promised not to do that.You know what, Papa. I have to watch you all the time.If you break little promises you'll break big ones. That's what you said.You always say that.What are you doing?Why?Why?Yes.I can't, I just can't...We could go over.We don't know what's in there.Okay. The boy sticks close to the MAN's side. The man has the revolver in his belt now and his parka unzipped, ready as they nervously walk towards the mouth of the tunnel.But you forget some things don't you?Okay.What is it? The MAN looks at the BOY, surprised he's talking again.Look. Colors.Look. It's clear.I don't know.Is it okay?What fire?Are we still the good guys?And we always will be no matter what happens? He eyes the BOY uncertainly, unsure if he can promise this.Do you think there could be fish in the lake?I'm hungry.Can I ask you something?Are we going to die?And we're still going south?So we'll be warm?And there might be food there?Okay. The MAN draws a blanket around him and kisses him goodnight, it is now pitch black.I wish I was with my mom. They are silent a moment, until:Yeah.I can't help it.How do I do that? The MAN is silent, lost in thought.Who are they, Papa?What if it's more bad guys?I'm scared.No. The BOY joins him and they set off slowly up the drive, through patches of melting snow. There is a tall dead privet fence with a deserted birdsnest in it.Papa?Papa, let's go.Don't open it - don't!No! The MAN goes out abruptly and the BOY follows, wringing his hands in fear.Papa...I'm going with you.Bad guys... bad men...What are you doing? The MAN's hand shakes, his thumb trembles on the hammer as he cocks it...Papa?Will I see you again? When will I see you? The MAN's finger trembles on the trigger as he slowly squeezes it... At that moment there's a loud THUMP from the kitchen and the WELL FED PEOPLE stop and listen, then rush through to the kitchen, and immediately there's a commotion as they see the state of the hatch with the table over it.They're going to eat those people aren't they, Papa? The MAN does not answer.Papa? Papa, we wouldn't ever eat anybody would we?No matter how hungry we were. Even if we were starving?Because, because we're the good guys?And we're carrying the fire.It's bubbly.It's really good. You have some, papa.But I want you to have some. The MAN reluctantly takes the can and has a tiny sip, hands it back to the wary BOY.It's because I'll never get to drink another one, isn't it? The MAN doesn't know what to say.What was that?Listen.A dog! Where did it come from?We're not going to kill it are we Papa?You still got one bullet left.Can we look for it?What is it?What is this place, Papa?I don't want to.There might be somebody in there.I'm scared.I'm not hungry. I'm not! The MAN takes his revolver from his belt and approaches the front door, warily pushing it open.Papa? I don't think we should do this.Stop - stop! The MAN freezes, then charges out.Wait! Come back! I won't hurt you!Where are you?! The MAN comes sprinting up the side of the house and seizes him by the arm.There's a little boy, Papa, I saw a little boy.Yes there is! I saw him! A boy just like me. The MAN takes the BOY by the arm and drags him back through the yard, up the side of the house, the BOY resisting, crying and looking back all the way.Why? Why can't I go and see him?I need to see him! I need to!I just do! The BOY has gone limp, weeping bitterly, resisting being moved. The MAN gives up and squats beside the sobbing BOY.Papa? Will there be other boys like me at the coast?What is it?Did you ever have any friends? The MAN eyes the BOY - curious at the sudden question.Lots of them?Do you remember them?What happened to them?All of them?Do you know where we are Papa?"As the crow flies?"There aren't any crows are there? Just in books.Do you think there might be crows somewhere?But what do you think?Could they fly to Mars or some place?Because it's too far?What if they tried and-and-and they just got halfway or something and then they were too tired? Would they fall back down...?Why, Papa?Will they see our tracks?What are we going to do? No answer.What's happening?That's all there is, isn't it?There's nothing left anywhere.Can I ask you something?Are we going to die now? The MAN just looks at the BOY, then looks away.Papa! What if there's people hiding down there? The MAN ignores him, focussed as he chops the plywood around the lock, gets the spade under a corner and levers the door open. The BOY has his fists bunched up to his chest, bobbing up and down with fear. The MAN starts to descend a hand made wooden stair case in the bunker. He takes another disposable lighter from his pocket, gives the child a kiss on the forehead and then disappears into the bunker, leaving the worried BOY staring after him. The BOY looks around at the deserted yard as the evening draws in, now even more frightened.What is it, Papa?Papa? What did you find?What is all this stuff?"Pears." It says "pears."Is it real?Why is it here?But they died.Pears.Is it okay for us to take it?What do I eat first?Is this coffee?We did good, didn't we Papa?Don't touch my stuff.Nice and warm. He washes the BOY's hair, lathing water over him with the pot. He has a sudden thought:Weird. The MAN doesn't know what to say, losing patience.Do you always expect it? Papa?You always think bad things are going to happen but we found this place. Here. The OLD MAN doesn't move.What about a spoon?Eat it. It's good. The OLD MAN picks up the tin and his filthy long nails CLATTER on the tin as he tips it to his mouth, the juice running down his chin, his head jerking as he swallows.Look, Papa. He's hungry.What's the question?He can't see.He's going to die and you don't care.You always say watch out for bad guys but that old man wasn't a bad guy and you can't even tell anymore.I had a bad dream.I don't want to tell you. Just you.Do you think they're still following us?What is it?I don't want to. Let's just keep going.What if they're bad guys?Why?No.Here?Is it blue?It smells different.What's on the other side?There must be something.And they could be carrying the fire too?What are our long term goals?I don't know. The BOY bends away and vomits and the MAN helps, rubbing his back and wiping the BOY's mouth when he's done.I'm sorry.Don't leave me here, don't go away Papa. Not even for a minute.Hi Papa.I know. The BOY shuts his eyes and goes back to sleep. The MAN strokes the BOY's hair tenderly, takes the pistol from his belt and carefully hides the pistol under the blanket by the boy's side. He stands, takes one last look and walks away...A man! There was a man! I saw a man.What happened?I don't know what we're doing.I don't know why we're doing this.We don't need them!Papa?Papa please don't kill the man.Please Papa.Papa.Oh papa.I can't stop it.I don't want to learn!I can't. The BOY looks back one last time as the THIEF disappears from view - still just standing there, utterly lost. The MAN stops and puts his shoes on. He walks back up the road to the bend but the THIEF has gone.He's not gone. He's not. The MAN looks helplessly at the tearful BOY as he fits his shoes on for him, the tears streaking the soot on his face.Just help him, Papa. Just help him. The MAN looks back down the road, weighing it up.He was just hungry Papa. He's going to die.He's so scared.Yes I am. I am the one. The MAN stops and faces-the innocent BOY angrily, stares, then relenting, summons all his strength, turns the trolley around and they start wheeling it back the way they came.He's afraid to answer.I don't know. Finally the MAN piles the THIEF's shoes and clothes in the road. He puts a rock on top of them.I don't want it.What would you do if I died?So you could be with me?Papa? The MAN rouses himself, sits up and just stares at the BOY, amazed, as if he has arisen from the graveI feel kind of weird.Just thirsty. The MAN gets up and fetches water from a ferry can in the trolley, pours a cup, hands it to the BOY who drinks thirstily. The MAN reaches out and strokes the BOY's hair as he drinks.Can I tell you something?You tell me I shouldn't cry but I've heard you crying. The MAN eyes the BOY, amazed at this inopportune chat.No.Your stories aren't true.In the stories we're always helping people. But we don't help people. We just shoot people.
